quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Every time I give them something, it vanishes. Then later I’m asked to prove I ever sent it.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Yes, and that’s why I’ve said to them they need to confirm receipt in writing.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But if they won’t confirm, then it’s just my word against theirs.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, which is why I’ve kept my own log to show when things were sent.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But your log isn’t official. They hold the file, not us.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: True, but if they contradict, we can show the timeline from our side.

contradictions.issue: Victim highlights evidence vanishing vs. advocate admits only secondary log exists; official file controlled by police

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: So if their file says one thing and your log says another, who do you think they’ll believe?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, and that’s why I always push for confirmation from them directly.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But they don’t give it. They stay silent or say they can’t find it.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Yes, that’s been the problem all along.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Then what’s the point of me giving anything, if it’s just going to disappear or be denied?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Because it still shows you’ve done your part, and I can evidence that you tried.

contradictions.issue: Police silence and denials vs. advocate insists victim should keep submitting evidence anyway

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: It just feels like I’m being set up to fail, no matter what I do.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I can see why you’d feel that way, and I don’t want you to feel set up.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But it’s the reality. The more I give them, the more they lose or deny.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and that’s why I keep challenging them to account for it.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Yet nothing changes.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: It’s very frustrating, I agree.

contradictions.issue: Victim describes systemic setup to fail vs. advocate concedes frustration but offers no resolution

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: They act confused when I say evidence is missing, then ask me to send it again like it’s the first time.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Yes, and that’s why I’ve said they need to keep proper logs to avoid this cycle.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But it’s not a cycle, it’s a tactic. They know what they’re doing.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I can’t say if it’s deliberate, but I know it feels deliberate to you.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Of course it feels deliberate, because no system loses things this many times by accident.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, Ben, and I’ll keep pressing them on it.

contradictions.issue: Victim asserts deliberate evidence erasure vs. advocate frames as system failure but concedes perception of intent

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: It wears me down having to resend things over and over, like they’re testing how long I’ll last.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, and I’ve told them it’s not acceptable practice.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Not acceptable? It’s abusive. They’re abusing the process to exhaust me.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I hear you, Ben, but I can’t confirm intent. What I can do is keep raising it.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Intent doesn’t matter when the effect is the same—me being broken down.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: That’s true, and I’ll keep highlighting the impact on you.

contradictions.issue: Victim frames resubmission cycle as abusive attrition; advocate refuses to confirm intent but concedes harm

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: So when they delete or lose my evidence, who’s accountable for that?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: That’s supposed to be the officer in charge, but it hasn’t been clear.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Exactly. If no one’s accountable, then it keeps happening.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and I’ve said they need to name who’s responsible for evidence handling.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But they won’t, will they?

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Not so far, no.

contradictions.issue: Officer in charge meant to be accountable for evidence, yet no named responsibility ever provided

timeline_hooks.ref: no accountability leads to repeat losses

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: So the chain of custody is broken, and no one admits it.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Yes, that’s why I’ve asked for a clear record of what’s been received and when.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: But until that exists, my case is basically unprovable.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, and I’ve pressed that it has to be formalised.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Pressed? It should already exist by law.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: You’re right, Ben. It should.

contradictions.issue: Chain of custody broken with no accountability; advocate admits record should exist by law but it doesn’t

timeline_hooks.link: Legal breach of evidence handling duties

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: And if the chain’s broken, the whole case collapses in court.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: That’s the danger, yes. Which is why I’ve told them it has to be rectified.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Told them? It should never have been broken in the first place.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I agree, it shouldn’t. But I can only push from my side.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: And while you push, I’m the one left unsafe.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, Ben, and I’m sorry you feel left unsafe.

contradictions.issue: Chain of custody broken undermining case; advocate concedes risk but deflects responsibility

timeline_hooks.link: Court risk due to broken chain of custody

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: So at this point, it looks like they want it to collapse.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I can’t say that’s their intent, but I know that’s how it feels given the gaps.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Feels like? It’s obvious when the same mistakes keep happening.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I agree the repetition is unacceptable, and I’ve raised that.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Raised it isn’t the same as fixing it.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and I wish I could give you a clear resolution right now.

contradictions.issue: Victim asserts systemic failure intentional; advocate avoids intent but concedes repetition is unacceptable

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: If they keep repeating the same failures, at some point it stops being a mistake.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I understand, and that’s why I’ve kept stressing it to them as a pattern.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Pattern is just another word for intent when it harms me every time.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I can’t label intent, but I can highlight that the effect is harmful.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Exactly. Impact matters more than what they claim their intent is.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I agree, and I’ve told them that as well.

contradictions.issue: Victim equates repeated failures with intent; advocate avoids intent but concedes harmful impact

timeline_hooks.link: Safeguarding breach through repeated harmful effects

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: So when they tell you it’s just delays, that’s not true—it’s repeated harm.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I know, and I’ve said delays are not an excuse when it affects your safety.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: Yet they still use it as an excuse.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: Yes, they fall back on it too often.

quotes.speaker: Ben Carter
quotes.quote: So excuses are accepted instead of accountability.

quotes.speaker: Emma Veritas
quotes.quote: I agree, and I’ve challenged them on that point.

contradictions.issue: Delays framed as excuse vs. reality of repeated harm; advocate concedes but system unchanged
